intro: Lupinus argenteus var. stenophyllus, commonly known as silver lupine, is a perennial legume native to the western United States. It is characterized by its silvery-gray foliage and erect, sparsely branched stems. The plant produces showy, pea-like flowers in shades of pink to purple, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in dry, rocky habitats. This variety is valued for its ornamental appeal and nitrogen-fixing capabilities, making it useful in ecological restoration projects.
